awd_titl_txt: REU Site: REU Program at University of Texas at Arlington (UTA): Assistive Technologies for People with Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
In this Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site, the Department of Computer Science and Engineering (CSE), in partnership with several other departments at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), proposes a REU program focusing on assistive technologies (AT) for people with disabilities (PWD). Undergraduate students are quite capable of performing tangible research, given the right motivation, facilities, mentoring, and guidance. Moreover, participation in active research can greatly enhance their educational experience and can be effective in motivating them to graduate studies. The proposed theme encompasses innovative and novel topics that can help PWD meet barriers of different kinds - attitudinal, architectural, and technological - in accessing employment, navigating public spaces, freely communicating, and living independently. Our REU program is a summer-long research experience for 10 carefully selected participants. The program includes close mentoring that will provide participants with a balance between technology research focus and grounding in pragmatic aspects that shape PWD's lives and assistive applications. The program also encompasses five weeks of intensive training in scientific research techniques and the technical areas, followed by five weeks of instruction in broader aspects of computer coding, technical writing, presentation skills, and aspects of a graduate career. The proposed innovative theme will excite students intellectually, as well as supporting their passion and creativity.

People who have disabilities make up one of the largest minorities in the world. The World Health Organization estimates as many as 975 million of those 15 years of age and older live with disabilities. For PWD, AT can create a positive influence by removing or reducing many barriers. AT include devices, systems, equipment, and software that make inclusive environments possible and thereby allow PWD to participate fully in society. Through close and frequent interactions between faculty and participants, the proposed theme of AT will expose participants to innovative and novel inter-disciplinary projects through research and prototyping. In the proposed REU program of CSE at UTA, participants will work on computer programming, algorithms, sensors, data analytics, machine learning, and as well as other aspects of basic and applied computer science and engineering. The prototype projects undertaken by REU participants, even though small in nature, will contribute towards inventive methods, techniques, systems, and apps by enhancing the fundamental knowledge base in related fields, while creating new avenues for cross-disciplinary research. By incorporating an important theme of AT in the diversity-rich UTA environment, we expect to increase the pool of diverse and talents students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
(1) We had a successful and satisfying 10-week summer program in wwhich10 students participated.

(2) We recruited 5 females and 3 students with minority backgrounds.

(3) We recruited 7 students from institutions with low research activity.

(4) We recruited only 3 UTA students.

The 10 students engaged in successful 5 research projects, which are described as below:

CLAIM (Composite Learning ASL Integrated Model):

 CLAIM and its underlying trained neural network recognize ASL signs accurately. Without accurate sign translations, the student quizzing themselves may not make much progress in learning ASL. The data used in training our neural network comes from an open-access, uncategorized database called WLASL (World-Level American Sign Language), which consists of 2,000 common words in ASL (20 of which we utilized). Each of the 20 signs we chose is associated with 8-plus training videos, which come from various websites – mostly ones focused on ASL education – such as signingsavvy.com, handspeak.com, and aslsearch.com. These videos vary in length but average about three seconds each. If a sign was associated with more than eight videos, we chose the best eight in terms of quality based on the resolution and size of the video.

 

Chef Robot for making Tortillas:

By the age of 90, 68.2% of men and 82.2% of women in the United States experience difficulties with physical and cognitive functioning. With the decline of physical and cognitive functioning, simple tasks, such as preparing meals, require assistance from either a caretaker or medical technologies. This project aims to create a chef robot for making simple tacos. Specifically utilizing the Kinova Robot Jaco, we designed a robot that can flip and cook a tortilla based on a data analysis algorithm. Using simulation, we evaluated two different parameters of the robotic arm to determine the optimal environment for preparing a tortilla.

 

A fidget device that maximizes the rehabilitation process:

Current rehabilitation methods appear to lack options for non-invasive mobility and sustainability. In Order to improve rehabilitation effectiveness, we have invented a device that helps support physical therapy by improving the effectiveness of different motor function models. This therapy-supporting device allows the user to have non-invasive real-time supervision, which enables the accurate and up-to-date status of the user by quantifying upper limb motion data and analyzing the data. By enabling a real-time update of the user’s status, it allows precise evaluation of the user, which can maximize the rehabilitation process for the patients. Not only can it quantify the motion data, by implementing force sensors and getting Kg data, as grip strength is known to be a useful indicator for the overall health of a person, but it also enables to indicate the healthiness of the user effectively. Additional advantages are solving the problem of the cost, needing to physically be at the clinic, lack of motivation, and need for manpower. By being in friendly and carriable shape and size and cheap, it can also motivate patients to be more continuous and consistent.

 

Smart Glasses for assisting people with buying grocery items:

For those with memory loss, everyday tasks are harder to accomplish. One of those everyday tasks is being able to buy groceries and shop for the home. Exploring this vein of research, we are looking to use Smart Glasses as an aid for users that allows them to communicate with online shopping more effectively. Users can click a widget that says, “scan groceries”, now the processor component of glasses can decode the scanning results and can automatically identify groceries using Object Detection and add them to a user’s shopping list stored on the E-commerce App.  

 

EEG and EOG classification Proposed Solution:

There has been a growing need for assistive technology for those with disabilities. One assistive technology that is drawing rapt attention is the “smart wheelchair.” There are different forms of this smart wheelchair, one of which is hands-free. A hands-free smart wheelchair receives commands from the wheelchair user in a mode alternative to a typical control component, the joystick. One way the wheelchair can maneuver their environment is through some sort of waveforms (brain and eye signals) of the wheelchair user. EEG (electroencephalogram) and EOG (electrooculogram) are used as a classification within this project. Our project is creating a solution to create an optimal EEG and EOG classification model using LSTM. The general computer science problem that our project is aiming to solve is EEG and EOG classification, and we propose using LSTM as an optimal form of classification.
